title: Certified upcycled foods continue to gain traction with the category projected to reach $80b by 2032 - FoodNavigator-USA.com
summary: The Upcycled Trade Association has grown rapidly since its founding in 2019, with 260 member companies and 454 certified products and ingredients in the market. The association's clear definition of upcycled food and its certification program have helped to drive growth and protect against greenwashing. The trade group is focused on consumer education and working with retailers and brands to communicate the value of upcycled foods.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article describes an innovation that contributes to environmental sustainability goals by reducing food waste and promoting the use of sustainable ingredients.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article describes the Upcycled Certified certification, which is a new or improved business process that differs significantly from previous processes and has been brought into use in the firm.
green_product: TRUE - The article describes upcycled food, which is a green product that is made from ingredients that would have otherwise been wasted.
green_process: TRUE - The article describes the Upcycled Certified certification process, which is a green process that helps to ensure that upcycled products meet certain environmental standards.
likely_naics_codes: ['311119 - Other Animal Food Manufacturing', '311211 - Flour Milling', '311225 - Fats and Oils Refining and Blending', '311812 - Commercial Bakeries']
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not describe an example of greenwashing.

title: Upcycled flour replacement introduced at IFT FIRST - BakingBusiness.com
summary: Renewal Mill has debuted its 100% upcycled, total flour replacement blend at IFT FIRST. The product offers more fiber and protein per serving than whole wheat flour. It is neutral tasting, pale tan flour that produces a golden tan crumb in applications like cakes, cookies, muffins and crackers.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the product contributes to environmental sustainability by reducing food waste and greenhouse gas emissions associated with food production.
business_innovation: TRUE, because the article describes a new and improved product (a flour blend) that differs significantly from the company's previous products.
green_product: TRUE, because the product is designed to significantly reduce its environmental impact throughout its life cycle by using upcycled ingredients and producing a neutral tasting, pale tan flour.
green_process: FALSE, because the article does not describe a process that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: ['311211 - Flour Milling', '311225 - Breakfast Cereal Manufacturing', '311812 - Commercial Bakeries', '311999 - All Other Food Manufacturing']
greenwashing: FALSE, because the article provides evidence to support the environmental sustainability claims made about the product.

title: Food product quality, environmental and personal characteristics affecting consumer perception toward food - Frontiers
summary: 1. This article discusses the factors influencing consumer perception of food, including sensory properties, packaging, and personal and environmental factors such as religion, ethics, socio-demographic variables, consumer age, consumer health, and awareness. 2. The article explores consumer decision-making processes that impact the food industry and discusses consumer approaches to innovative food systems. 3. The article concludes with remarks and future perspectives on various factors influencing consumer perception of food.
greenwashing: This article does not provide enough information to determine whether the described product or process innovation is an example of greenwashing.
